head.title: Film in Review; Downtown -- A Street Tale

hedline.hl1: Film in Review; Downtown -- A Street Tale

abstract.p: Jeannette Catsoulis reviews film Downtown: A Street Tale, directed by Rafal Zielinski; Joey Dedio and Genevive Bujold star (M)

block.p: Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Rafal Zielinski 103 minutes

A hackneyed melodrama partly redeemed by a cast convinced that it's performing Tennessee Williams, ''Downtown: A Street Tale'' follows a bunch of stereotypically damaged people in an abandoned building in New York. Rehashing characters and plots from the ''Law & Order'' playbook, the director, Rafal Zielinski, supplements his material with religious iconography and more gauzy close-ups than a Barbra Streisand marathon. Prostitution, heroin and mental impairment have never looked so pretty.
Opens today in Manhattan. Directed by Rafal Zielinski 103 minutes

A hackneyed melodrama partly redeemed by a cast convinced that it's performing Tennessee Williams, ''Downtown: A Street Tale'' follows a bunch of stereotypically damaged people in an abandoned building in New York. Rehashing characters and plots from the ''Law & Order'' playbook, the director, Rafal Zielinski, supplements his material with religious iconography and more gauzy close-ups than a Barbra Streisand marathon. Prostitution, heroin and mental impairment have never looked so pretty.

Acting as surrogate parents to this makeshift family are Angelo (Joey Dedio, who also wrote the story), the oldest-looking rent boy in town, and Aimee (Genevi√®ve Bujold), a saintly shelter proprietor. Burt Young and John Savage also show up briefly -- as a genial sugar daddy and a wheelchair-bound pimp -- and Martin Scorsese's daughter, Domenica Cameron Scorsese, appears in a central role as a pregnant runaway. No amount of name recognition, however, can distract from the script's banalities; this tale, set at Christmas, is like a cross between ''West Side Story'' and a Nativity play.

Filmed in 2004 and only now drifting into limited release, ''Downtown: A Street Tale'' presents its broken protagonists as fallen angels, complete with fuzzy halos. In these not-so-mean streets, salvation is only a cinematographer away.
''Downtown: A Street Tale'' is rated R (Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian). It has shooting up, beating up and a whole bunch of acting up.
